thread.title: Marmitegate: Twitter reacts to the stand-off between Tesco and Unilever - Chronicle Live
thread.title_full: Marmitegate: Twitter reacts to the stand-off between Tesco and Unilever - Chronicle Live

author: Chris Knight
title: Marmitegate: Twitter reacts to the stand-off between Tesco and Unilever - Chronicle Live
text:
Marmitegate: Twitter reacts to the stand-off between Tesco and Unilever 13:46, 13 Oct 2016 13:55, 13 Oct 2016 By Chris Knight The supply of Marmite is one of many to be affected by the dispute, and social media has reacted to #Marmitegate Share Get what's on news by email Nick Potts/PA Wire Products made by Unilever 
Brexit has always been a controversial subject but #Marmitegate has well and truly set the powder keg alight. 
An alleged row has broken out between Tesco and one of their main suppliers Unilever, which has seen the supermarket giant pull numerous well-loved brands from their online shelves. 
Marmite, Ben and Jerry’s, Cornetto, Pot Noodle, PG Tips, and Walls and more are all currently unavailable for internet shoppers, and stocks in store are said to be running out. 
The news that Brexit might cause a serious shortage in Marmite in particular has sent social media wild, and here are some of the best reactions from Twitter: 
This scene from one of the earlier Harry Potter movies seems to capture the hysteria that has gripped Britain over the potential loss of Marmite. British people panic buying #Marmite perfectly sums up the hysterical insanity of 2016. #Marmitegate #Brexit pic.twitter.com/Yt0DS4TkLY — Tom King (@tallgeekychap) 13 October 2016 
First Killer Clowns, then Marmite? We dread to think what’s coming next! Pretty sure Marmite famine and rampaging Killer Clowns are both in the Book of Revelation as signs of the End Times. — Sinister Farce (@twlldun) 13 October 2016 
A reaction it seems many share following the news. When you realise @tesco have stopped selling marmite. #marmitegate pic.twitter.com/1E8nsJKIDp — Sarah Dean (@sarahdeancomms) 13 October 2016 
For some though, #Marmitegate is only touches the surface of the problem. @MartinShovel Daddies Brown Sauce is where I make my stand. #Marmitegate — Linda Mockett (@mframeg) 13 October 2016 
Is this the first casualty of the stand-off between Tesco and Unilever? NO MORE PG TIPS? — Ken Shabby (@MrKenShabby) 12 October 2016 
That is a hefty amount of Marmite to just be giving away in the current climate. Left the waiter a serious tip. pic.twitter.com/wnMK95oJoy — Jason Hazeley (@JasonHazeley) 13 October 2016 
We’re sure this was the discussion Viggo Mortensen was having with his on-screen son in the post-apocalypse movie The Road... "What did Marmite taste like father?" pic.twitter.com/Uai8JwS5z0 — Zorro P Freely (@banalyst) 12 October 2016 
The timing surely isn’t a coincidence. Wow. Scottish people really, really love Marmite https://t.co/sccS1qQzH5 
The jokes firmly on us now for not believing. Today I was MOCKED for keeping an emergency Marmite supply in my handbag. Two words. APOCALYPSE. READY. — Sybil Disobedience (@PaolaOeste) 12 October 2016 
Somebody’s clearly hit the jackpot. — Dave Williams (@realdavedoubleu) 13 October 2016 
We really wouldn’t recommend this... Just scored two jars of Marmite from a bloke in the park. Keith — Keith Mallender (@KeithMallender) 13 October 2016 
Is this the first signs of a crimewave following the news of #Marmageddon? Beware the Marmite touts outside Tesco. Links to organised crime, Bovril trafficking etc. — Simon Blackwell (@simonblackwell) 13 October 2016 
Despite the great pressure we’re now all under, there are some calls to remain calm. Good people of Britain. No matter how terrible this Marmite war becomes, we must not go to the dark side Vegemite #marmite #Marmitegate — Ben Fogle (@Benfogle) 13 October 2016 
In the midst of the hysteria, it is good to consider a little perspective. Our grandparents withstood bombing raids and rationing to protect our freedom. We are screeching about 10p on a jar of #Marmite . — Jamie Foster (@1jamiefoster) 13 October 2016 
Was this the deal that cost Sam Allardyce his job as England manager? "I can get you Marmite...but it's gonna cost you" pic.twitter.com/54hn2zhXWr 
And even our very own Gateshead MP Ian Mearns has joined in on the fun. Traffic already building eastbound on the M62 https://t.co/EIn1yybsGH
